Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: An REU Site in Interdisciplinary Chemistry at Oklahoma State University
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professors White, Mohanty, and colleagues in the Chemistry Department at Oklahoma State University host an Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site. This project is funded by the REU Sites Program in the Chemistry Division and the Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR) both at the National Science Foundation (NSF) to support 12 students for 10 weeks in each of the three grant years. This REU site exposes early career stage undergraduates to interdisciplinary research in modern chemical sciences, including advanced materials, chemical sensors, nanochemistry, and chemical biology. Broader impacts of this work include the exposure of all REU participants to industrial and government scientists, emphasizing broadened perspectives on chemistry careers, increasing exposure of students from underrepresented groups to the chemical sciences, and actively involving REU participants in the larger research landscape of a comprehensive doctoral research university. Oklahoma has one of the highest Native American populations in the country and specific relationships with faculty at four-year undergraduate institutions are in place to help facilitate their recruitment.

Nineteen active research groups host students at the Oklahoma State University REU Site. Examples of specific projects include investigations to promote understanding of how polymer chain organization influences the useful material properties of macromolecules, NMR studies of the effects of glycosylation on the structure, dynamics, and interactions of membrane proteins, and the development of earth-abundant transition metal complexes of N-heterocyclic carbenes. Other included projects range from synthetic methods development and drug synthesis to the development of organic semiconductors and electronic materials that can be used in organic electronics, sensors, and bioelectronics. Students recruited from the local area include Native Americans and students from primarily undergraduate schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The primary objective of the proposed Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Program in Chemistry at Oklahoma State University is to immerse students in a stimulating interdisciplinary research program that enables them to pursue a personalized research project.  The REU site at Oklahoma State University successfully completed three years of REU program training 12 undergraduate students/year for a total of 36 students in 3 years from across the USA including women and minority students. Delivering a successful research experience was the primary objective, but significant efforts were devoted towards other critical program outcomes, including (1) regular exposure of all REU participants to industrial (Cytovance Biologics, OKC and Chevron Phillips Chemical Company, LP, Bartlesville, OK) and government scientists, emphasizing broadened perspectives on chemistry careers; (2) increasing exposure of students from underrepresented groups to the chemical sciences; (3) actively involving REU participants in the larger research landscape of a comprehensive doctoral research university; (4) training in research ethics and laboratory safety; and (5) tutorials on literature/database usage and making effective scientific presentations to both expert and general audiences.  As needed, students were also trained in the use of high-field NMR instrumentation (400 and 600 MHz NMR Spectrometer), as well as other necessary equipment in the shared user facilities such as fluorescence spectrophotometer, circular dichroism (CD) spectropolarimeter, Mass Spectrometry, and Gas Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry (GC-MS).  

During these 3 years, a total of five peer-reviewed publications were reported by five different REU students during 2016-2019. These were published in high-quality scientific journals such as ‘Tetrahedron Letters’, ‘Synthesis’, ‘Molecules’, ‘Journal of Physical Chemistry’, and ‘Organic Process Research and Development’.  Many more REU students presented their REU research work at various National and International Scientific Conferences /Symposium such as National Science Foundation REU Symposium (CUR), and American Chemical Society. Total four students participated and presented their work in the NSF supported Council on Undergraduate Research (CUR) Symposium in Alexandria, VA between 2016-2019. In addition, several of our REU students joined graduate school including two students who joined our Chemistry Graduate Program at Oklahoma State University. 

Broader Impacts.

The REU proposal enabled undergraduate students within and outside of the state of Oklahoma to participate in a high-impact interdisciplinary research program in the Chemistry Department at Oklahoma State University.  The students were able to conduct research across various fields including organic, inorganic, biological and materials. This intense training over 10 weeks period helped to maintain the competitive position of the United States in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) fields. This REU site in the Chemistry Department at Oklahoma State University broadened the impact beyond Oklahoma state and enabled us to recruit and train undergraduate students across the USA. 

 

To enrich the REU experience for undergraduates, we partnered with a major Biotech company, Cytovance Biologics, located in the Research Park in the heart of Oklahoma City. Undergraduates participating in the REU program got the opportunity to visit with Cytovance Biologics. This one-day trip to the biotech company helped to understand the management of many diseases through biological products such as antibodies, and a guided tour of the company?s manufacturing plant including viewing of the detailed process of manufacturing and production of these products in large scale, the importance of maintaining sterile conditions and a perspective on research in an industrial setting along with the career opportunities available in this industry.  In addition, the REU participants also visited and interacted interact with scientists from Chevron Phillips Chemical Company, LP, located in Bartlesville, OK. This one-day trip again included the guided tour of the polymer manufacturing plants.
